**The Lost Generation of Democracy: Spain's Rise of the Far-Right**
Spain is joining the list of countries where young people are fueling the rise of the far-right and authoritarian ultraderecha. A decade ago, one in three young people expressed their intention to vote for the left, while only one in four thought they would vote for the right. However, in recent surveys, the correlation has been reversed: four in ten young people between 18 and 24 years old support the right (and two-thirds of them support the ultraderecha), while only two in ten choose left-wing options. This age group now accounts for over three million voters out of a total of 37 million. The most significant aspect of this ideological shift is the rapid and unprecedented growth of the ultraderecha among young people. In the CIS survey of May, the conservative space was divided equally between the Partido Popular (20%) and the ultraderecha of Vox and Alvise (22%) among those under 24. A similar correlation occurred in the 25-34 age group (a contingent that accounts for another five million voters). However, this pattern is maintained, intensified, in the CIS survey of July: the ultraderecha has a 13-point lead over the PP in the 18-24 age group, and more than six points in the next age group (25-34 years). The mutation of the ideological youth in Spain has no precedents. With the country just out of the dictatorship, young people leaned clearly to the left (and their location on the ideological scale reflected this, as they now sit one point to the right). Even in the early 90s, the percentage of young people under 35 who supported the PSOE or more left-wing forces doubled or even tripled the rate of adhesions to the right. The data from last May provides clues about the causes of this change. If the declared voting intention is segregated by sex, the result is very eloquent: among men aged 18-24, Vox outperforms the PP by almost eleven points (and seven in the 25-34 age group). However, among young women, it is the Partido Popular that outperforms the ultras: by 12 points in the 18-24 age group, and seven in the 25-34 age group. In short, the ultraderechization of young men has something of an egoistic rebellion against the advance of gender parity. Nevertheless, Spain is not an exceptional case. Other Western countries are experiencing a sustained rise in extreme right-wing parties with the decisive support of new generations.
